entry.title: Treasure Chaser
entry.summary: Are your memories treasure? Or are your visions of the future…
entry.content:
Are your memories treasure?

Or are your visions of the future the treasure?

What about the present?

Is right now considered a treasure?

They all seem pretty valuable.

Treasure hunters are an interesting group.

Chasing futures where they hope to find the valued past right now or somewhat soonish.

Someone's past, found in someone else's present, for yet another someone else's future.

Actually finding the treasure comes with all sorts of drama (like all big moments).

You may not even be able to keep it.

The law, ya know.

But the chase is yours.

They can't take that away.

How big is your fortune?

Is it vaulted in your heart?

Is it in the cloud in your brain?

Or can you touch it with your lips?

Are you the treasure?

Yours or anyone else's?

Somewhere between remembering and imagining is present day.

Vault, earth, cloud.

I'd say carpe diem or some ess, but I hear they cancelled Latin.

Sic Transit Gloria.

entry.title: Timelines
entry.summary: I almost forgot to write again. Some days just fly by.
entry.content:
I almost forgot to write again.

Some days just fly by.

Most days do.

As you get older, the seconds, minutes, hours, and days just seem a bit shorter.

Even the microwave timer I set for a few comfortable minutes seems to take me by surprise.

Already? I thought I had more time.

Kids never want the day to end.

They can spend an eternity in a day and still want it to last a little longer.

My little ones are how I measure time now.

I don't feel old.

I just act it.

Always have.

But when I see how big they're getting, well, do the math.

This is a very wonderful season. In the year. Of my life.

If you don't know by now, I believe time is the truest and most precious currency. 

And attention is how we pay.

Are you paying attention to how you spend your time?

Tick tock. 

Ever wonder why they call the app that?

entry.title: Guano
entry.summary: Ever hear the idea that insanity is doing the same thing…
entry.content:
Ever hear the idea that insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different result?

This is a mostly true statement.

But there are always exceptions to every rule. Exceptions so few that they prove the rule.

For example, do you know how they split really big rocks?

One person grabs a big hammer.

Said person smashes said hammer on big rock. 

It does nothing.

They smash it again in the same spot.

Over and over again.

Expecting it to crack.

It doesn't.

Not right away.

They just keep smacking the rock.

Same spot.

Over and over.

The key is patience. And knowing where and how to strike.

They just keep smashing away.

Then you know what happens?

After a long time, and a lot of reps, the rock just suddenly splits.

A bat ess crazy person probably discovered this.

So, for your consideration:

What are you doing, over and over, expecting a different result?

And are you splitting a rock or swinging at a shadow?

Three feet from gold or digging your own grave?

Find good hammer.

Find good rock. 

Find right spot to smash.

Smash rock in right spot.

Over and over.

Nothing happens.

Keep going.

Rock splits.

Good work.

Good rock.

Good human.

Next rock...

entry.title: Once Upon A Time
entry.summary: I'm just happy to be here. I know sometimes it's not…
entry.content:
I'm just happy to be here.

I know sometimes it's not clear.

That's the old curmudgeon in me.

But I've always been this way.

Right now, all of this, every single ridiculous post, is me reeling from the reality of how a man who plays the long game almost passes, but survives.

Lives to fight another day.

A most fortunate man.

How do you keep thinking and planning the future when you're just enjoying, and grateful for, today?

I tell those closest to me that I'm in my absurd phase.

I'm going for absurd.

It seems like a fun way to play it.

All of this, after all, is the stuff of fairy tales.

Magic and wonder.

I sit in awe of it all.

But if I'm not the same, the next question is, "Who in the world am I?" Ah! That's the great puzzle!

And they lived happily ever after.

entry.title: The End
entry.summary: You ever stick to something, just because you wanted to see…
entry.content:
You ever stick to something, just because you wanted to see how it ends?

Be it a book, a game, a movie, a tv show, a job?

Why do we do that?

Some sort of closure is needed. 

Even if you know it'll disappoint.

I'd like to think that wisdom is in knowing what to finish and what to just stop.

What is worth finishing?

What is worth stopping?

Oh, and don't worry.

I am still going to write here.

Just getting started.

entry.title: Do Overs
entry.summary: Would you do it again? I asked this question to the…
entry.content:
Would you do it again?

I asked this question to the wife of a well-known author, during a lunch we shared with our families. She had told us of all their struggles. And how they were thriving in the good.

Would she do it all again?

She hesitated, deep in thought.

After what felt like a minute, but was only a few long seconds, she said, "Yes, I would, but I wouldn't want to live through all of it again."

My wife and I traveled across the country to meet this couple.

At the time, I was searching for answers. 

I suppose I still am.

At the time, it felt like such a win, to be able to poke around the brain of someone you admired.

I don't remember a single thing about what he talked about.

But I remember her answer.

entry.title: Advice
entry.summary: Drake Maye is the quarterback for the New England Patriots. [This…
entry.content:
Drake Maye is the quarterback for the New England Patriots.

[This is my second post about New England Patriot quarterbacks. Weird.]

He said something the other day that I thought relevant.

He said:

"All the praise when you're successful and all the hatred when things go bad...Don't take criticism from someone you wouldn't take advice from."

It reminds me of a quote from an old friend.

"If the A-holes are mad at you, you're doing something right."

Today's world gives microphones and megaphones to voices of varying value and values.

Pick your mentors.

Pick your enemies.

May they never cross.

entry.title: Find Me Later
entry.summary: Say what you want about Google, but they are a verb.
entry.content:
Say what you want about Google, but they are a verb.

And the thing that struck me about their founders was what they said early on. Back before they dominated. When they were just search. And wondering how to monetize it.

As they were just beginning, as they were just gaining traction, they said something really interesting.

They said: The later you discover us, the better.

Meaning, they wanted people to find out about Google later. 

Why?

Because the team believed the later you found them, the better they would be. Their first impression would be more impressive.

In a world where most people want it and they want it now, there are still some of us who are like yeah, I got work to do, find me later.

Find me later.

I'm not saying I'd be better, but the later you find me, the better.

I got so much work to do.

But I'm trying. I'm trying real hard, Ringo.

To be the shepherd.

entry.title: Testing
entry.summary: 123. Type check. Will this update? I continue to tinker on…
entry.content:
123.

Type check.

Will this update?

I continue to tinker on this thing. 

Trying to learn every day.

Will this work? 

Let's find out!

Remember those days when we'd have to knock the side of the television to get it to work?

Technology is always improving, but you can't thump it anymore.

It's unthumpable.

And there are times when it just don't make sense. When the urge to thump rises.

And you got to adjust, you gotta tinker. I would say iterate, but yeah, that's not the right word.

Clouds and locals. 

Syncs and backups.

Fixed this issue, it seems, but it really wasn't an issue.

Just redundancy.

A Plan B.

Two is one, you know.
